Heritrix will download any kind of document that it finds a link to. It IS
=
limited to http only (wont crawl links to documents on FTP servers for
inst=
ance) but this is rarely an issue.
 
Link extraction is generally limited t=
o text document, although there is a
PDF, Flash and a Word document parsers=
 that have provided mixed results. 
 
- Kris

thnx for encouraging me for=
 using Heritrix.. :-D

Since i am new to Heritrix, i may have several fooli=
sh questions in 
my mind..So here i am firing one more query to u..

Can He=
ritrix download any kind of documents(for eg. pdf, doc, rtf, 
etc...) or it=
 Is restricted to "Text" only...

with regards,
Shadab

awler@yahoogroups.com, "Kristinn Sigurdsson" 
<kris@a...> wrote:
>
> 1. Not=
 as such, although there was an issue with Heritrix builds 
failing on
> 2.=
6 kernels at some point. Myself, I'm running on Red Hat, but 
that is
> sim=
ply because thats what we use here, not because Heritrix runs 
better on
> =
it. (Michael, I think there should be a FAQ entry for this 
question). Just=

> make sure you've got Java 1.4.2 or better installed and you should 
be f=
ine. 
>  
> 2. Depends on the hardware. Assuming that there are enough acti=
ve 
queues
> (meaning the KB/sec is not limited by politness rules) the cra=
wler 
is
> capable of (in my experiance) going as high 21.1 Mbits/sec (over=
 a 
period of
> 24 hours). Peak loads can be higher, especially if you are =

downloading a lot
> of larger files. If many crawling text documents, band=
width usage 
drops,
> since each text document is subjected to link extract=
ion that 
takes time.
> The throughput in terms of documents per second for=
 the 24 hour 
period cited
> above was approx. 57 docs/sec. (about 5 millio=
n docs and 214GB of
> uncompressed data in 24 hours).
>  
> The hardware in=
 question includes dual Xeon processors and 2 gigs 
worth of
> memory (+ ab=
undant disk storage). Heritrix likes processor power 
in my
> experience, i=
ts performance is usually limited by this factor 
although
> additional mem=
ory can somewhat improve throughput for high end 
machines.
>  
> 3. Yep, r=
ead the User Manual. It has a section on installation 
and "A quick
> guide=
 to running your first crawl job" which should get you up and 
running
> in=
 no time. 
http://crawler.archive.org/articles/user_manual.html#tutorial
> =
 
> - Kris
